awd_titl_txt: Towards a Holistic Model for Outer Membrane Protein Sorting in the Periplasm
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will employ a combination of mathematical modeling and experimentation to develop an integrated, holistic view of the essential process of sorting proteins into membranes in bacteria. This research will lead to novel insights into how bacteria, which live in soil, water, and on the surfaces of animal cells, grow and mature. The PI will engage in outreach to K-12 students, and provide training to graduate and undergraduate students who will participate in the research project and have the opportunity to present their work at national scientific meetings.

The long-term goal of this project is to develop a quantitative description of the flux of membrane proteins through the periplasm and into the outer membranes of E. coli. The project will develop a global mathematical model that uses ordinary differential equations to describe outer membrane protein chaperone interactions and membrane protein maturation in gram-negative bacteria. The model will be tested and optimized by experimental data on the interaction kinetics and thermodynamics of all pairwise interactions. In this manner, the holistic mathematical description will stay fully grounded by rigorous experimental data. A major goal of the project is to determine whether or not parallel pathways exist for the sorting of outer membrane proteins into outer membranes.

This award is jointly supported by the Cellular Dynamics and Function Cluster and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, and by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

por.por_cntn:
Research - With this NSF support, we have conducted computational and experimental studies to probe the rules of life. The work has specifically led to the development of a novel network model that describes chaperone network in bacteria. Complementing this computational model were experiments to test and improve the reactions and parameters included in the model. The principle emergent property arising from the network model is shows that functional redundancy in the chaperone molecules function to suppress accumulation of unfolded membrane proteins. The chaperones do this by playing a “hot potato” game with the unfolded membrane proteins. Because the association and dissociation of unfolded membrane proteins to chaperones is very fast, the chaperone network can be thought of as a set of proteins quickly “tossing around” and unfolded membrane protein. This dynamic back and forth means that an unfolded membrane protein spends most of its time bound to a chaperone, thus preventing its free concentration from building up. In cases where a build-up starts to happen, the network senses the initial build up and displays two response: (1) The first is a “buffering” function implicit in the locally expressed chaperone levels. This buffering function can absorb a small increase in unfolded membrane protein accumulation. (2) The second is a concerted increase in the amounts of chaperone proteins by signaling to the cell nucleus to synthesize more of them. 

Education – Our country must harvest all of the talent available to it to continue its competitive advantage, and this means that representation in science must reflect represent representation in our general public. The work for this project works to nurture a more inclusive scientific community for enhanced diversity and inclusion by daily discussions of these issues, public presentations and writings and by conducting workshops to promote normalization of the conversations around bias. The actual work of the project has expanded the participation of women and minorities in the scientific enterprise through research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students. These students developed expertise in cutting edge scientific methods and experiments. In addition, students receive training in writing and oral presentations. Finally, this award allowed all members of the laboratory the opportunity to attend national scientific meetings and present their research findings.

Modified by: Karen G Fleming
